Content Summary: This paper discusses the number of derangements of a set of numbers.

Title: Regula facilis problemata Diophantea per numeros integros expedite resolvendi
English Title: An easy rule for Diophantine problems which are to be resolved quickly by integral numbers
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 4, pp. 3-17.
Content Summary: Euler returns to the problem of making formulas of the form axx+bx+g into squares. He generalizes to try to find a and b solving axx+bx+g = zyy+hy+t. This seems to rely on an initial solution and a clever application of solutions to Pell’s equation. He does some nice examples: (1) find all triangular numbers that are also squares, (2) find all square numbers that, diminshed by one, are triangular numbers, (3) find those triangular numbers that, when tripled, are again triangular numbers.

Title: De lineis curvis non in eodem plano sitis, quae maximi minimive proprietate sunt praeditae
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 4, pp. 18-42.

Title: Analysis facilis aequationem Riccatianam per fractionem continuam resolvendi
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 4, pp. 12-29.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, the equations in question are linear partial differential equations with constant coefficients.

Title: Observationes circa fractiones continuas in hac forma contentas S = n/(1+(n+1)/(2+(n+2)/(3+(n+3)/(4+etc.))))
English Title: Observations about continued fractions contained in the form S = n/(1+(n+1)/(2+(n+2)/(3+(n+3)/(4+etc.))))
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 4, pp. 52-74.
Content Summary: This paper contains recursive formulas, continued fractions, and material found elsewhere, as in section 57 of the Calculi Differentialis.

Title: De serie maxime memorabili, qua potestas binomialis quaecunque exprimi potest
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 4, pp. 75-87.
Content Summary: This time, Euler expands (1+x)a in terms of binomial-like coefficients and factors of the form xn/(1+x2).

Title: De divisoribus numerorum in forma mxx+nyy contentorum
English Title: On divisors of numbers of the form mxx + nyy
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 5, pp. 3-23.
Content Summary: First, Euler notes that divisors of xx+yy (x and y relatively prime) must be of the form 4N+1, then that divisors of 2xx+yy must be of the form 8N+1 or 8N+3, and those of 3xx+yy are of the form 12N+1 or 12N+7. He generalizes this result by analyzing the divisors of mxx+nyy. Interestingly, one can state the congruence classes modulo 4mn which hold divisors of mxx+nyy once one knows the value of the product mn, regardless of the particular values of m and n. Euler presents a table of congruence classes modulo 4mn holding divisors of mxx+nyy for small values of mn.

Title: De fractionibus continuis Wallisii
English Title: On the continued fractions of Wallis
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 5, pp. 24-44.

Title: Methodus succincta summas serierum infinitarum per formulas differentiales investigandi
English Title: A method for gathering the sums of infinite series by investigating differential formulas
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 5, pp. 45-56.
Content Summary: This paper consists of more formal reciprocal series with Bernoulli numbers. In today's language: Euler evaluated the Riemann zeta function Î¶(s) at even positive integers.

Title: De seriebus memorabilibus, quibus sinus et cosinus angulorum multiplorum exprimere licet
English Title: On remarkable series, by which the sines and cosines of multiplied angles may be expressed
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 5, pp. 57-72.
Content Summary: Euler begins with a power series expansion of cos(2xw) using binomial coefficients and unknown factors to the coefficients A, B, C, …, does a similar thing for sin(2xw), and gets a couple of series expansions in terms of sin(nw) and sinnw.

Title: Investigatio quadrilateri, in quo singularum angulorum sinus datam inter se teneant rationem, ubi artificia prorsus singularia in Analysi Diophantea occurrunt
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 5, pp. 73-95.
Content Summary: Euler reduces this to a Diophantine problem: given four square numbers aa, bb, cc, and dd, find two numbers z and v such that z–aav, z–bbv, z–ccv and z–ddv are all square numbers.

Title: Geometrica et sphaerica quaedam
English Title: About geometry and spheres
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 5, pp. 96-114.
Content Summary: This paper is about certain geometry and spheres, the main theorem being "In whatever triangle ABC, straight lines Aa, Bb, Cc are drawn from the angles to the opposite sides so that they all meet at some point O, then they will always have the following property AO/Oa ∙ BO/Ob ∙ CO/Oc = AO/Oa + BO/Ob + CO/Oc + 2."

Title: Commentatio in fractionem continuam, qua illustris La Grange potestates binomiales expressit
English Title: A commentary on the continued fraction by which the illustrious La Grange has expressed the binomial powers
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 6, pp. 3-11.
Content Summary: Euler gives a continued fraction representation for (1+x)n involving 1, 3, 5, 7, ..., and n2–1, n2–4, n3–9, ..., and squares of z, for x=2y and y=z/(1–z). He evaluates this continued fraction at z=tâ-1, for "vanishing" n, and for infinite n.

Title: Analysis facilis aequationem Riccatianam per fractionem continuam resolvendi
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 6, pp. 12-29.

Title: De integralibus quibusdam inventu difficillimis
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 6, pp. 30-53.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, this work concerns a certain family of definite integrals.

Title: Solution succincta et elegans problematis, quo quaeruntur tres numeri tales, ut tam summae quam differentiae binorum sint quadrata
English Title: Solution succincta et elegans problematis, quo quaeruntur tres numeri tales, ut tam summae quam differentiae binorum sint quadrata
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 6, pp. 54-65.
Content Summary: The problem, according to Euler: "Let x, y and z be the three numbers being sought, of which the largest is x and the smallest z, and let x=pp+qq and y=2pq, so that x+y=(p+q)2 and x–y = (p–q)2. In the same way, setting x=rr+ss and z=2rs, then x+z=(r+s)2 and x–z=(r–s)2. In addition to these four conditions being satisfied, it must be that rr+ss = pp+qq. Then, two additional conditions must be added, that y+z = 2pq+2rs and y–z = 2pq–2rs must both be squares." Euler gets x=50, y=50, z=14, then x=733025, y=488000, z=418304. Then, characteristically, he proposes a slightly different problem (section 16) and solves it by the same means.

Title: Probleme de geometrie resolu par l'analyse de Diophante
English Title: On a problem of geometry resolved by Diophantine analysis
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 7, pp. 3-9.

Title: De casibus, quibus formulam x4+mxxyy+y4 ad quadratum reducere licet
English Title: On cases for which the formula x4+mxxyy+y4 can be reduced to a square
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 7, pp. 10-22.
Archive Notes: Italian translation
Content Summary: Euler first dismisses the obvious cases when x=y and m=2 or when one of the values is zero. Then he goes on to solve the problem, finding about 90 values of m less than 200 for which solutions exist (section 13). He closes with a "more elegant solution."

Title: Solutio problematis mechanici non parum curiosi
English Title: Solution to some curious problems of mechanics
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 7, pp. 23-32.

Title: De problemate traiectoriarum orthogonalium ad superficies translato
English Title: On the problem of orthogonal trajectories, translated to surfaces
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 7, pp. 33-60.

Title: De binis formulis speciei xx+myy et xx+nyy inter se concordibus et discordibus
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 8, pp. 3-16.
Content Summary: Two forms are called concordant if there exist values of x and y that make both forms into squares at the same time. If they are not concordant, they are called discordant. For example, xx+yy and xx–yy are discordant, while xx+yy and xx+7yy are concordant (e.g., x=3, y=4). Euler seems to get partial results.

Title: Investigatio accuratior circa brachystochronas
English Title: A more accurate investigation into brachistochrones
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 8, pp. 17-28.

Title: De vera brachystochrona seu linea celerrimi descensus in medio resistente
English Title: On true brachistochrones or lines of the fastest descent in a resistant medium
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 8, pp. 29-40.
Content Summary: Euler again considers friction. He takes a rigorous variational approach to determine the optimal curve, assuming that the friction takes the form hvn+1. He evokes his isoperimetric theorem, but mentions that he has to refine this theorem in order to be able to apply it to the case where velocity depends on arc length – a situation where friction is considered. He succeeds and produces a very generalized version of our modern-day Euler-Lagrange equations, after which he finds that the brachistochrone equation reads (n+2) dv/(vv) − (n+1)C dv √(1+pp)/(pv) + C(1−(h/g)vn+1√(1+pp))∙d(√(1+pp)/p) = 0, where C is some constant, g is half the gravitational acceleration and p=dy/dx. He then proceeds to reduce this equation to √(1+pp) − cp/v + (h/g)vn+1(p/θ−1) = 0, where c=1/C and θ is the tangent of the angle of the end of the curve. Euler then considers two cases of the equation: n=0 (the frictionless brachistochrone solution, i.e., a cycloid) and n=-1 (constant friction with relatively simple equations for x and y).

Title: De brachystochrona in medio resistente, dum corpus ad centrum virium utunque attrahitur
English Title: On the brachistochrone in a resistant medium while a body is attracted to a center of forces in one way or another
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 8, pp. 41-45.

Title: Lettera inedita di Eulero a Lagrange
English Title: Unpublished letter from Euler to Lagrange
Original Source Citation: Biblioteca Italiana, Volume 30, pp. 111-112.
Archive Notes: The Euler Archive's copy of the letter was originally printed in Œuvres de Lagrange 14, Paris 1892, pp. 208-209.

Title: De tribus pluribusve numeris inveniendis, quorum summa sit quadratum, quadratorum vero summa biquadratum
English Title: On finding three or more numbers, the sum of which is a square, while the sum of the squares is a fourth power
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 9, pp. 3-13.
Content Summary: Euler attributes this problem to Fermat and says he heard it from Lagrange: to find three numbers, x, y, and z such that x+y+z is a square and xx+yy+zz is a fourth power. He starts with a two-variable problem, asking that x+y be square and xx+yy a fourth power. He finds a pair of numbers in the trillions. Then he finds a three-variable solution x=49, y=64, z=8 and goes on to four variables (x=193, y=104, z=48, v=16) and even five variables.

Title: Resolutio facilis quaestionis difficillimae, qua haec formula maxime generalis vvzz(axx+byy)2 + Δxxyy(avv+bzz)2 ad quadratum reduci postulatur
English Title: An easy resolution to a most difficult question, where this most general form vvzz(axx+byy)2 + Δxxyy(avv+bzz)2 is required to be reduced to a square
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 9, pp. 14-19.
Content Summary: Euler considers quadratic forms axx+2bxy+cyy, a little more general than his usual form. Biquadratic forms didn't seem to take off, though.

Title: De problemate curvarum synchronarum, eiusque imprimis inverso
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 9, pp. 20-34.

Title: Methodus nova et generalis problema synchronarum inversum aliaque eiusdem generis resolvendi
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 9, pp. 35-46.

Title: De curvis quarum radii osculi tenent rationem duplicatam distantiae a puncto fixo earumque mirabilibus proprietatibus
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 9, pp. 47-56.

Title: De unciis potestatum binomii earumque interpolatione
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 9, pp. 57-76.
Content Summary: Euler again expresses binomial coefficients as integrals.

Title: Solutio problematis Fermatiani de duobus numeris, quorum summa sit quadratum, quadratorum vero summa biquadratum, ad mentem illustris La Grange adornata
English Title: A solution to a problem of Fermat, on two numbers of which the sum is a square and the sum of their squares is a biquadrate, inspired by the Illustrious La Grange
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 10, pp. 3-6.
Content Summary: Euler returns to the problem, motivated by Lagrange, of finding x and y such that x+y is a square and xx+yy is a fourth power. This is a very short paper.

Title: Enodatio maximi paradoxi, in problemate quodam mechanico occurentis
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 10, pp. 7-15.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, the titlular problem is 'Invenire curvam AYZ, super qua corpus descendens secundum horizontem AB motu uniformiter accelerato progrediatur, ita ut tempus per AY sit in ratione subduplicata abscissae AX.'

Title: Solutio trium problematum difficiliorum ad methodum tangentium inversam pertinentium
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 10, pp. 16-26.

Title: De insigni promotione Analysis Diophantaeae
English Title: On a notable advancement of Diophantine analysis
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 1-11.

Title: Solutio problematis difficillimi, quo hae duae formulae aaxx+bbyy et aayy+bbxx quadrata reddi debent
English Title: A solution of a most difficult problem, in which the two forms aaxx+bbyy and aayy+bbxx must be rendered into squares
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 12-30.
Content Summary: Euler first finds three families of particular solutions to the problem, then proceeds to a general solution. Finally, he extends the problem to finding a, b, c, and d that make all of the following three expressions into squares: aabb+ccdd, aacc+bbdd, aadd+bbcc.

Title: Investigatio binorum numerorum formae xy(x4–y4), quorum productum sive quotus sit quadratum
English Title: An investigation of two numbers of the form xy(x4–y4), of which the product and the quotient will be a square
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 31-45.
Content Summary: In Volume XV of the Novi Commentarii, Euler found integers x, y, z such that xy±z(x+y) and xy±z(x−y) are all squares. In this paper, he describes a more elegant solution, which first requires one to determine when xy(x4−y4) is a square. Then, given an initial solution, he uses a double-quadratic technique to find a chain of solutions.

Title: De binis numeris, quorum summa sive aucta sive minuta tam unius quam alterius quadrato producat quadrata
English Title: On two numbers, of which the sum when increased or decreased by the square of one of them produces a square
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 46-48.
Content Summary: Euler seeks x, y, and z so that (x+y)/z ± xx/(zz) and (x+y)/z ± yy/(zz) are both squares.

Title: Dilucidationes circa binas summas duorum biquadratorum inter se aequales
English Title: Elucidations about two sums of pairs of biquadratics, which are mutually equal
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 49-57.
Content Summary: Euler shows that A4 + B4 = C4 + D4 for A = 477069, B = 8497, C = 310319, D = 428397 and for some other sets of values.

Title: De resolutione huius aequationis 0 = a + bx + cy + dxx + exy + fyy + gxxy + hyy + ixxyy per numeros rationales
English Title: On the resolution of the equation 0 = a + bx + cy + dxx + exy + fyy + gxxy + hyy + ixxyy by rational numbers
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 58-68.
Content Summary: Euler presents techniques for factoring biquadratics, such as 0 = a + bx + cy + dxx + exy + fyy + gxxy + hyy + ixxyy.

Title: Methodus nova et facilis formulas cubicas et biquadraticas ad quadratum reducendi
English Title: A new and easy method for reducing cubic and biquadratic forms to squares
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 69-91.

Title: Solutio problematis ad analysin infinitorum indeterminatorum referendi
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 92-94.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, Euler's goal is to define a function x(v) so that when p, q, r, s, t, … are given functions of v, then all integrals of p dx, q dx, r dx, s dx, t dx, … can be evaluated.

Title: De infinitis curvis algebraicis, quarum longitudo indefinita arcui elliptico aequatur
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 95-99.

Title: De infinitis curvis algebraicis, quarum longitudo arcui parabolico aequatur
English Title: On the infinity of algebraic curves, whose longitude is equal to a parabolic arc
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 100-101.

Title: De binis curvis algebraicis eadem rectificatione gaudentibus
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 102-113.

Title: De curvis algebraicis, quarum omnes arcus per arcus circulares metiri liceat
English Title: On algebraic curves, all of whose arcs may be measured by circular arcs
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 114-124.

Title: Solutio problematis analytici difficillimi
English Title: Solution to a very difficult analytical problem
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 125-130.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, Euler's goal is to define a function Π(x, y) so that when p, q, P, and Q are all functions of x/y, the integral ∫[(p dx + Π q dy)/(Π P + Q)]∙xn–1 can be evaluated.

Title: Intégration d'une espèce remarqable d'équation différentielle dans l'analyse des fonctions à deux variables
English Title: Integration of a remarkable type of differential equation in the analysis of two-variable functions
Original Source Citation: Mémoires de l'académie des sciences de St.-Petersbourg, Volume 11, pp. 131-137.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, Euler integrates a special nth-order partial differential equation that has two independent variables.

Title: Œuvres complètes en français de L. Euler
English Title: The complete works of L. Euler in French
Original Source Citation: Brussels: Établissement géographique près la porte de Flandre, Volume 2018-01-05.
Archive Notes: This work was published in Brussels in 1839, comprising five volumes. The Euler Archive has only been able to locate an electronic copy of Volume 1.

Title: Solutio problematis in Actis Lipsiensibus A. 1745 propositi
English Title: Solution of a problem proposed in the Leipzig Acts in 1745
Original Source Citation: Correspondance mathématique et physique de quelques célèbres géomètres du XVIIIème siècle, Volume 1, pp. 341-354.
Content Summary: This work is an unpublished manuscript that Euler enclosed along with a letter he wrote to Goldbach. According to Eneström, the titular problem is 'Circa datum focum C describere curvam AEBF, ut omnes radii ex C emissi post binas reflexiones in M et N factus, in ipsum punctum C revertantur.'

Title: Briefe von L. Euler an Chr. Goldbach 1729-1763
English Title: Letters of L. Euler and Chr. Goldbach, 1729-1763
Original Source Citation: Correspondance mathématique et physique de quelques célèbres géomètres du XVIIIème siècle, Volume 1, pp. 3-672.
Archive Notes: What Eneström refers to as E788 is Euler's half of the Goldbach correspondence (or at least that part published in Fuss's Correspondance). The Euler Archive has copies for most letters in its correspondence section.

Title: Einige Zeilen aus einem Brief von L. Euler an Albrecht von Haller vom 4 Juli 1744
English Title: A few lines from a letter of L. Euler to Albrecht von Haller, from 4 July 1744
Original Source Citation: "Auszuge aus Briefen von Albrecht von Hallee, mit litterarish-hisorishen Notizen," Mittheilungen der naturforschenden Gesellschaft in Bern, pp. 27-28.

Title: Commentatio de matheseos sublimioris utilitate
English Title: Commentary on the use of sublime mathematics
Original Source Citation: Journal fur die reine und angewandte Mathematik, Volume 35, pp. 109-116.
Archive Notes: An English translation of this work appears in The Early Mathematics of Leonhard Euler, by C. Edward Sandifer, published by the Mathematical Association of America in 2007. Sandifer and Robert Bradley collaborated in the translation.

Title: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae
English Title: Collected arithmetical commentaries
Original Source Citation: St. Petersburg: Imperial Academy of Sciences, Volume 2018-01-02, pp. 1-584, 1-651.
Content Summary: The two volumes together contain 94 numbered treatises and five further “Additamenta.”

Title: Tractatus de numerorum doctrina capita XVI, quae supersunt
English Title: Treatise on the doctrine of numbers
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 503-575.
Content Summary: This is the start of a book on number theory, in 17 chapters. Quadratic residues are given in paragraph 343 of Chapter 10, with cubic residues in paragraph 370 of Chapter 11. Feuter notes that, beginning in paragraph 400, some of Euler’s proofs are incomplete.

Title: Considerationes circa Analysin Diophanteam
English Title: Thoughts concerning Diophantine analysis
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 576-587.
Content Summary: The first two paragraphs seem to be in praise of Diophantine analysis. Then we turn to familiar ground: first, find three numbers, v, x, y that make squares out of the expressions vx+v+x, vy+v+y, and xy+x+y. Next, find four numbers A, B, C, D that make the following squares: AB–1, AC–1, AD–1, BC–1, BD–1, and CD–1. (An easy solution is 1, 2, 5, 1.) Given a number n, find four numbers that make squares out of AB+n, AC+n, etc.

Title: Theorema arithmeticum eiusque demonstratio
English Title: A theorem of arithmetic and its proof
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 588-592.
Content Summary: In this paper, Euler proves that for m unequal positive integers a, b, c, d, ..., the sum of fractions an/[(a–b)(a–c)(a–d)...] + bn/[(b–a)(b–c)(b–d)...] + cn/[(c–a)(c–b)(c–d)...] + dn/[(d–a)(d–b)(d–c)...] + ... is equal to 0 for n≤m–2, and he gives a general formula for the sum of these fractions for n=1, n=m and n>m. He shows a direct relationship between the values of the sum of these fractions for higher n and the coefficients of the polynomial (z–a)(z–b)(z–c)....

Title: De quadratis magicis
English Title: On magic squares
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 593-602.
Content Summary: Euler shows how to construct magic squares with a certain number of cells, in particular 9, 16, 25, and 36. He also considers some general rules for constructing squares of even and odd orders. He starts with Graeco-Latin squares and puts constraints on the values of the variables so that the result is a magic square.

Title: Recherches sur le probleme de trois nombres carres tels que la somme de deux quelconques moins le troisieme fasse un nombre carre
English Title: Research into the problem of three square numbers such that the sum of any two less the third one provides a square number
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 603-616.
Content Summary: In the first part, Euler presents several different methods of finding values of x, y, and z that make the following three expressions all squares: yy+zz–xx, xx+zz–yy, xx+yy–zz. In the second part, entitled "Solution to a rather curious known problem: to find four positive numbers, unequal among themselves, such that the sum of any two is always a square," Euler presents several solutions, by familiar means. The third part is entitled "Supplement to the problem of four given numbers of which the sum of two always makes a square number."

Title: Recherches ulterueures et tres curieuses sur le probleme de quatre nombres positifs et un proportion arithmetique tels que la somme de deux quelconques soit toujours un nombre carre
English Title: Further and curious research into the problem of four positive numbers and an arithmetical proportion such that the sum of any two is always a square number
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 617-625.

Title: De numeris amicibilibus
English Title: On amicable numbers
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 627-636.
Content Summary: This paper continues much earlier work on amicable numbers, including Euler's comments on the existence and properties of odd perfect numbers (section 8). This manuscript is unfinished; sections and tables are missing.

Title: Fragmenta commentationis cuiusdam maioris, de invenienda relatione enter latera triangulorum, quorum area rationaliter exprimi possit, et de triangulo in quo rectae ex singulis angulis latera opposita bisecantes sint rationales
English Title: A fragment of a commentary, the most part on finding the relation between the sides of triangles of which the area is able to be expressed rationally, and of triangles in which the lines from each angle bisecting the opposite line are rationals
Original Source Citation: Commentationes arithmeticae collectae, Volume 2, pp. 648-651.
Content Summary: Euler discusses rational trigonometry.

Title: Brief von L. Euler an Christoph Jezler vom 4 Mai 1765
English Title: A letter from L. Euler to Christoph Jezler, dated 4 May 1765
Original Source Citation: Bern: Mittheilungen der naturforschenden Gesellschaft, Volume 1851, pp. 53-58.

Title: Drei Briefe von L. Euler an Friedrich den Grossen 1743
English Title: Three letters of Euler to Frederick the Great in 1743
Original Source Citation: Œuvres de Frédéric le Grand, Volume 20, pp. 199-203.

Title: Opera Postuma mathematica et physica
English Title: Posthumous works in mathematics and physics
Content Summary: Published in 1862, the Opera Postuma was a two-volume publication by the St. Petersburg Academy of Sciences containing all the works of Euler that had not yet been published. Compiled by P. H. Fuss, the volume contained 59 unpublished works of Euler, which Eneström numbered as E792-E799 and E806-E856.
Record Created: St. Petersburg: Imperial Academy of Sciences, Volume 2018-01-02, pp. 1-588, 1-826.

Title: Problema algebraicum de inveniendis quatuor numeris ex datis totidem productis uniuscuiusque horum numerorum in summas trium reliquorum
English Title: An algebraic problem of finding four numbers with the sum of the three others
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 1, pp. 282-287.
Content Summary: Euler considers the following problem: Given a, b, c, d with a = v(x+y+z), b = x(v+y+z), c = y(v+x+z), and d = z(v+x+y), determine v, x, y, and z. He changes variables to arrive at four "nice" equations, each in terms of a new variable u and the constants a, b, c, and d.

Title: Series maxime idoneae pro circuli quadratura proxime invenienda
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 1, pp. 288-298.
Content Summary: Euler calculates π to 20 decimal places.

Title: Enodatio insignis cuiusdam paradoxi circa multiplicationem angulorum observati
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 1, pp. 299-314.
Content Summary: Euler looks at the power series for f(x) = (1 + √(1–x))n. Again, complex variable subsitutions seem to save the day.

Title: Vera aestimatio sortis in ludis
English Title: The true valuation of the risk in games
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 1, pp. 315-318.
Content Summary: This paper is about the St. Petersburg problem. Its content is similar to that of Daniel Bernoulli's "Specimen theoriae novae de mensura sortis."

Title: Réflexions sur un espèce singulière de loterie, nommée Loterie génoise

Content Summary: According to Eneström, this is an application of differential calculus to geometry.

Title: Problematis ex theoria maximorum et minimorum solutio
English Title: Solution of problems from the theory of maxima and minima
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 1, pp. 403-407.
Content Summary: According to Eneström, the problem is "Super recta AB constituere trangulum AOB, ut si ex dato puncto V in sublimi posito ducantur rectae VA, VB et VO, sit summa binorum triangulorum AVO + BVO minima."

Title: Considérations sur quelques formules intégrales dont les valeurs peuvent être exprimeés, en certains cas, par la quadrature du cercle
English Title: Thoughts on certain integral formulas for which the values can be expressed under certain circumstances by the squaring of the circle
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 1, pp. 408-438.
Content Summary: This paper is concerned with several families of definite integrals of rational functions, which, upon integration, have values expressible purely in terms of trigonometric functions.

(Based on Eric J. Aiton's introduction to Opera Omnia Series 2, Volume 31.)

Title: Recensio Dissertationis de ventis
Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 2, pp. 793-797.
Content Summary: This is a review of d'Alembert's essay Reflèxions sur la cause générale des vents on winds. Euler praises d'Alembert's essay especially for its mathematical analysis, in which there is an extensive application of partial differential equations. (Based on Eric J. Aiton's introduction to Opera Omnia Series 2, Volume 31.)

Title: Meditatio in experimenta explosione tormentorum nuper instituta

Original Source Citation: Opera Postuma, Volume 2, pp. 800-804.
Archive Notes: An English translation of excerpts of this work (by Florian Cajori) appears in David E. Smith's Source Book in Mathematics (1929, McGraw-Hill), pp. 95-99.
Content Summary: This article has achieved lasting fame in mathematical footnote history by being the first printed source in which e is used to represent the base of the natural logarithm. Euler wrote this paper at the end of 1727 or at the beginning of 1728, when he was just 21 years old, describing seven experiments performed between August 21 and September 2, 1727.
